Reportedly, the pressure has intensified following the ‘botched’ launch of Meta’s Llama 4 AI model, which was hit by reports of underwhelming real-world performance, poor coding ability and allegations of rigged benchmark scores.CNBC recently reported that Alexandr Wang, chief AI officer of Meta AI, is facing the heat. Wang is tasked to deliver a top-tier AI model that helps the company regain momentum against rivals like Google and OpenAI, the publication reported citing people familiar with the matter. That pressure has increased as Google unveiled Gemini 3.0 last month to a positive reception. Meanwhile, OpenAI has also upped its game with GPT-5 and, more recently, GPT-5.2. Anthropic also debuted the Claude Opus 4.5 model in November.The 28-year-old executive heads the elite internal unit known as TBD Lab, and Avocado is being developed under his watch. The people familiar with the matter said the model is said to be grappling with various training-related performance tests which are essential to ensure the system is well-received when it eventually debuts. Notably, the model was scheduled to launch in 2025 but the unveiling has reportedly been pushed to the first quarter of 2026.Along with Wang, Nat Friedman is also under pressure, as he has been tasked with producing a breakout AI product, the people said. Under Friedman’s watch, Meta launched Vibes, a feed of AI-generated short videos, in September but it is widely viewed as inferior to OpenAI’s Sora 2, the people noted. This is because of criticism for being rushed to market and lacking key features, such as the ability to generate realistic lip-synced audio.The pressure is also being felt by employees who are reportedly working 70 hours per week as the company cut hundreds of jobs and underwent restructurings throughout the year. Employees are also conflicted on the way things are being done in the company.Meta has traditionally sought input from numerous groups responsible for areas like front-end user interface, design, algorithmic feeds and privacy for uniformity among the company’s apps, the people said. However, the products are reportedly not developed to accommodate foundation models, which Friedman views as bottlenecks responsible for slowing down ‘a rapid-fire development process’.Friedman has called for the use of newer tools that have been calibrated to incorporate multiple AI models and various kinds of coding automation software often called AI agents, the people said.
Article Summary: The pressure has intensified following the ‘botched’ launch of Meta’s Llama 4 AI model, which was hit by reports of underwhelming real-world performance and poor coding ability. The company is said to be working on Avocado – new Llama successor and frontier AI model – which is being developed inside TBD lab.

Article Title: Cisco CFO Mark Patterson makes fun of Hewlett Packard Enterprise, says: The networking company you bought for $14 billion is ...
Article Text:
FILE - (AP Photo/Elise Amendola, file)

Hewlett Packard Enterprise acquires Juniper Networks for $14 billion





Corporate rivalry is common and so is top executives mocking rival companies/their products. In one such case, Cisco chief financial officer (CFO) Mark Patterson took potshots at rival Hewlett Packard Enterprise's $14 billion acquisition of Juniper. Speaking at an investors event, Cisco CFO Mark Patterson took pointed strikes at Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE). Patterson told an audience at the recent Barclays Technology, Media, Telecom (TMT) Conference that Cisco has been able to take advantage of continued market uncertainty emanating from HPE’s Juniper Network integration. “I think that as HPE and Juniper come together they have a lot of overlap and probably their best performing space, which is wireless, so that's causing, I think, a lot of confusion with customers and what's going to happen there, and we've certainly been able to, I think, capitalize on that,” Patterson said.Patterson’s HPE comments echoed that of former Cisco CFO Scott Herren, who during an investor conference last year said that HPE’s then pending purchase of Juniper Networks has left many enterprise wondering. “I think for sure that's created just a degree of uncertainty and a question of, hey, should I consider if I was previously a vendor or a customer of either of those, now is the time to kind of open up and look at other opportunities,” Herren said at that time.“And we've seen our wireless business, our orders greater than $1 million grew more than 20% in the fourth quarter.”Cisco is the world's largest networking company. Founded in 1996, Juniper spent many years chasing Cisco in the market for networking gear since decades.In January 2024, Hewlett Packard Enterprise announced that it has agreed to buy networking gear vendor Juniper Networks for about $14 billion, or $40 per share, in an all-cash deal. The acquisition would double HPE’s existing networking business after years of competition. Hewlett-Packard went deeper in networking when it bought Aruba Networks in 2015. Months later, HP split in two, resulting in the formation of HPE, which sells servers and other equipment for data centers, and HP Inc, which makes PCs and printers. HPE then said that adding Juniper to its portfolio would bolster margins and speed up growth.In June 2025, HPE struck a conditional agreement with the US Department of Justice (DoJ) that cleared the way for the company's $14 billion acquisition of Juniper Networks, an M&A deal that the DoJ had been trying to block on antitrust grounds.
Article Summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) announced that it has agreed to buy networking gear vendor Juniper Networks for about $14 billion, or $40 per share, in an all- cash deal. The acquisition would double HPE’s existing networking business after years of competition.

Article Title: The great memory squeeze: Why AI is making your gadgets expensive
Article Text:
A global memory chip shortage, driven by insatiable AI data center demand, is skyrocketing prices for everyday electronics. Manufacturers are prioritizing lucrative AI clients, leading to reduced consumer supply and higher costs for smartphones, laptops, and PCs. This fundamental market shift means technology is becoming less accessible and more expensive for everyone.

Three companies you've never heard of control everything

Disclaimer: This image is generated using AI.

When family ties break and brands die

Every device you own gets more expensive

The bill comes due (and it's not optional)





If you've been eyeing a new laptop, planning to upgrade your PC, or even considering a smartphone purchase lately, you might want to sit down for this. The world is experiencing a memory crisis of unprecedented proportions, and it's about to hit your wallet harder than you think.The numbers tell a stark story. That RAM stick you could have picked up for Rs 6,000 in August? It's now hovering around Rs 15,000. DDR5 sticks now start at about Rs 40,000 with prices soaring as high as over a lakh for a 32 gigs one. That’s when, if you can find one. A solid-state drive that would have set you back Rs 6,000 six months ago might now cost you close to Rs 19,000. We're not talking about modest price corrections or seasonal fluctuations—this is a full-blown market disruption, and artificial intelligence is the culprit.The immediate pain is most visible among PC enthusiasts and gamers. Online retailers have started listing memory modules with fluctuating daily prices, treating them less like computer components and more like commodities on a trading floor. Some retailers have gone so far as to restrict purchases to one unit per customer, attempting to curb hoarding.But this is just the opening act. The real drama unfolds when you realise that every device with a chip inside—your smartphone, laptop, gaming console, smart TV, even your car—relies on the same memory that's currently being devoured by the AI industry's sprawling data centres.Pop quiz: name the three companies that manufacture the memory inside your phone.Don't feel bad if you're drawing a blank. Samsung you might know, though probably for their phones, not their chips. SK Hynix? Micron? These aren't household names. They don't advertise during cricket matches. They don't have sleek retail stores. Most people could live their entire lives without knowing these companies exist.And yet, together, they control 93% of the world's DRAM production—the memory that powers virtually every electronic device you touch. Your smartphone, laptop, tablet, gaming console, smart TV, car dashboard. All running on chips from this three-company oligopoly.For years, this arrangement hummed along invisibly. They competed for market share, prices stayed reasonable, technology improved steadily. The system worked well enough that nobody paid attention.Then it broke. Spectacularly.SK Hynix just posted profits that more than doubled year-over-year—from Rs 32,800 crore to Rs 71,900 crore. Micron's annual net income didn't just grow; it multiplied tenfold. These aren't the numbers of companies struggling to meet demand. These are the numbers of companies that found a way to print money, and that way is called artificial intelligence.Here's what's happening: AI companies are building data centers at a pace that defies comprehension. OpenAI's Stargate project alone—just one initiative from one company—plans to spend $500 billion over four years. Half a trillion dollars. That's more than the GDP of Poland. Of Thailand. Of entire nations.These data centers need memory. Mountains of it. Specialised high-bandwidth memory (HBM) that can process massive datasets at speeds that make your laptop RAM look like a carrier pigeon. And here's the problem: that specialised memory comes from the same factories, uses the same equipment, competes for the same silicon wafers as the regular memory that goes into consumer devices.Samsung and SK Hynix reportedly signed a deal to supply OpenAI with up to 900,000 DRAM wafers monthly. That's roughly 40% of global production—gone, locked up, spoken for. Imagine if someone bought 40% of the world's wheat harvest. What would happen to bread prices?Now imagine that, except the bread is the chips inside everything you own.The memory manufacturers aren't scrambling to fix this imbalance. They're celebrating it. Samsung told investors—and this is worth reading carefully—that it would "pursue a strategy of maintaining long-term profitability" rather than rapidly expanding production. Translation: Why make more chips and risk prices falling when scarcity is this profitable?SK Hynix was even more explicit. In their recent earnings call, they celebrated "the highest-ever quarterly performance, driven by the full-scale rise in prices of DRAM and NAND." Operating profit exceeded 10 trillion won for the first time in company history. They're not treating this as a crisis to solve. They're treating it as a windfall to harvest.The incentive structure is perfectly perverse. Manufacturing capacity takes years and billions to expand. Why invest heavily in new plants when current scarcity lets you charge premium prices? Why flood the market when controlled supply maximises profits? These companies learned painful lessons in 2023 when oversupply tanked prices and hurt revenues. They're not eager to repeat that mistake, even if it means years of constrained consumer supply.The absurdity of this situation crystallised in two stories that reveal everything about where priorities now lie.First: Samsung Semiconductor reportedly refused a memory order from Samsung Electronics. Let that sink in. The same company. Different divisions, yes—Samsung is less a company than a constellation of affiliates—but still. Samsung's mobile division, preparing for its 2026 flagship smartphones, approached Samsung's semiconductor division for memory chips. They wanted to lock in pricing and supply for the year, standard practice in manufacturing.Samsung Semiconductor said no.Not "we can't meet those volumes." Not "let's negotiate pricing." Just no. According to reports, the semiconductor division rejected the long-term deal entirely, forcing the mobile division to renegotiate quarterly at higher prices. They eventually hammered out a short-term agreement, but the precedent is staggering.Think about what this means. Samsung's own phone business—one of the largest smartphone manufacturers in the world—cannot secure favourable memory pricing from its sister company because AI data center customers will pay more. The 12GB of memory in a flagship smartphone now reportedly costs Samsung nearly Rs 3,350 more than it did months ago. That's not retail price—that's what it costs Samsung to put Samsung memory into Samsung phones.If Samsung can't get reasonable memory prices from Samsung, what chance do smaller manufacturers have?Second: After 29 years, Micron is killing Crucial, their consumer memory brand. No more Crucial RAM. No more Crucial SSDs. All shipments cease February 2026.If you're not into PC building, that name might mean nothing. But Crucial was a pillar—one of the oldest, most trusted names in consumer memory. Reliable, affordable, available everywhere. Tech reviewers recommended it reflexively. Builders planned around it. The brand represented a kind of social contract: decent performance at fair prices for people building their own machines.That contract just got torn up.Micron's statement used the sanitised language of corporate strategy: exiting the consumer business to "improve supply and support for larger, strategic customers in faster-growing segments." Strip away the euphemisms and it's simple: AI companies pay better, so we're selling to them instead.The decision is financially rational. Brutally, perfectly rational. Crucial products sold at competitive consumer prices with thin margins. AI server memory commands premium pricing with guaranteed long-term contracts. If you're Micron's executive team, explaining to shareholders why you're still bothering with consumer products becomes increasingly difficult.But the implications extend beyond one brand disappearing. With Micron gone, Samsung and SK Hynix now control roughly 70% of consumer DRAM. That's not just reduced competition—that's approaching monopoly territory. And monopolies, as any economics textbook will tell you, don't typically result in lower prices and better service.There's also symbolic weight to Crucial's shutdown. This was a 29-year-old brand, spanning generations of PC builders. People built their first computer with Crucial memory. Upgraded their parents' computers with Crucial RAM. The brand had cultural currency beyond its market share. Its death sends a message: consumer DIY computing is no longer a priority. The industry is moving on, and if you want to come along, you'll pay premium prices for whatever capacity they deign to allocate to you.The PC gaming community felt it first. Memory kits that held steady around Rs 8,000 for months suddenly jumped to Rs 18,000. Then Rs 38,000. Premium configurations now cost over Rs 40,000—for memory alone. Some retailers stopped listing fixed prices entirely, treating memory like crude oil with prices fluctuating hourly. In Japan, stores implemented rationing—one memory kit per customer—trying to prevent hoarding.Online forums filled with digital despair. People who'd saved for months, planned their builds meticulously, waiting for the right moment. Except the right moment never came. It got worse instead. Framework—a company philosophically built on user-upgradeable laptops—stopped selling standalone memory modules because scalpers bought everything instantly. CyberPowerPC announced memory prices up 500%, SSDs up 100%, with increases effective December 7. A specific date. This is when affordable PC building dies.But the shockwaves are spreading far beyond gaming rigs.Dell's COO admitted he's "never seen memory-chip costs rise this fast"—not during the pandemic, not ever. Industry sources say Dell is preparing price increases of 15-20%, possibly effective mid-December. Lenovo sent notices to business clients: all current quotations expire January 1, 2026. HP's CEO acknowledged that memory represents 15-18% of a typical laptop's cost, and when that component doubles in price, the math becomes brutal.Here's what most consumers won't see coming: manufacturers facing rising costs have three options—raise prices, eat the cost, or cut corners elsewhere. Guess which one they're choosing.Start looking for smaller batteries. Cheaper displays with dimmer panels and narrower color gamuts. Reduced storage because who needs local storage when everyone's pushing cloud subscriptions? Less expensive cooling systems that degrade faster. Build quality that slips in ways that don't appear on spec sheets but become glaringly obvious after a year of use. The budget laptop segment—those Rs 30,000 machines that get students through college—is facing existential crisis. A Rs 3,000 increase in memory costs represents a 10% price jump on devices already operating on razor-thin margins.TrendForce revised its 2026 notebook forecast from 1.7% growth to a 2.4% decline. That's millions of laptops that won't be sold because people either can't afford them or won't accept the compromises.Smartphones face the same squeeze. Industry analysts predict an average Rs 750 price increase across smartphones in 2026, with shipments declining as consumers balk or delay upgrades. Budget phones—devices under Rs 20,000 that represent the majority of global sales—will suffer most. That Rs 18,000 phone that came with 6GB of RAM might drop to 4GB. Storage shrinks from 128GB to 64GB. Cheaper cameras. Slower charging. The phone still works, but it's quietly, frustratingly worse than what the same money bought six months ago.Gaming consoles aren't immune. Hardware that traditionally holds pricing stable for entire generations faces another Rs 12,500 increase on top of previous bumps. Even Raspberry Pi—the tiny computer beloved by educators and hobbyists, philosophically committed to accessibility—raised prices between Rs 420 and Rs 2,100 per model.Storage drives are experiencing their own quiet crisis. SSDs use NAND flash memory, and AI data centers need massive storage for training datasets. A one-terabyte drive that cost Rs 6,000 in August now ranges from Rs 7,000 to Rs 9,000. High-performance models have nearly tripled where stock has evaporated. The CEO of a major SSD controller manufacturer warned that current supply tightness could last a decade. Even traditional hard drives are seeing shortages and price increases as cloud providers buy everything available.What makes this particularly cruel: storage needs keep growing inexorably. Operating systems expand with each update. Games routinely exceed 100GB. Everyone shoots videos in higher resolutions. Just as storage becomes more essential, it's becoming more expensive and scarce.Strip away the technical details and one question remains: who's paying for the AI revolution?Tech companies and investors are betting hundreds of billions that AI will reshape everything and generate returns justifying these massive infrastructure investments. They're reorganising entire supply chains around this vision. Meanwhile, everyone who uses technology—which is everyone—is subsidising this bet through higher prices and reduced availability. Your more expensive phone. Your pricier laptop. Your delayed computer upgrade. These are the hidden costs of the AI boom that nobody includes in the marketing presentations.There's profound irony here. AI promises to democratise capabilities, make technology more accessible. Yet building the infrastructure for these promises is actively making technology less accessible. Local hardware is becoming prohibitively expensive, pushing computing to the cloud—to those same data centers causing the shortage. You become dependent on subscriptions and internet connections for capabilities that could theoretically run on your device, if only the components weren't so costly.Some analysts call this a bubble. OpenAI has reportedly secured over $1.5 trillion in infrastructure commitments while generating approximately $12 billion in annual revenue. That's a lot of future promises riding on present spending. If they're right, memory prices could crash as suddenly as they spiked. But bubbles can inflate for years before popping. The dot-com bubble took years. The housing bubble took years. In the meantime, we all live with the consequences.Industry forecasts agree: this deteriorates before it improves. Most analysts expect prices climbing through mid-2026 at minimum. SK Hynix told investors the shortage could persist through late 2027. That's years of a fundamentally altered market.Building new semiconductor fabrication plants takes time—years, not months. Micron is planning a facility that won't begin construction until May and won't ship products until 2028. SK Hynix announced over $500 billion in new plant investments, with the first operational in 2027. These aren't solutions for people who need to buy a laptop next year or the year after.And there's another bomb waiting: Windows 10 support ends in October 2025. Millions of computers will need replacement or upgrades to meet Windows 11 requirements—newer processors, TPM 2.0 chips, and yes, more memory. This injects massive demand into a constrained supply chain at exactly the worst possible time.For consumers, the calculus is grim. Buy now before prices climb higher? Wait for relief that might not arrive for years? Accept compromises on specifications and performance? The advice circulating tech communities is blunt and depressing: if you need memory, storage, or a new device, buy now. Today's painful prices will likely look reasonable compared to tomorrow's. It's the kind of recommendation that feels fundamentally wrong—waiting usually means better deals, better technology, better value. But that's the old world.This is the memory crisis. Not a temporary shortage. Not a market fluctuation. A fundamental reordering of priorities that puts consumers at the back of the line while AI companies cut to the front. Unlike a natural disaster or pandemic that disrupts supply chains, this is a choice. Companies are choosing to prioritise AI over consumers because the economics make sense—for them.That memory in your current phone? It's worth more than it was six months ago, not because it got better, but because someone else wants it more. The laptop you'll buy next year? It'll cost more than it should, not because it's improved, but because the components inside are being rationed to serve priorities that have nothing to do with you.The AI revolution is here, and you're paying for it whether you wanted to or not. In higher device costs. In compromised specifications. In delayed upgrades. In the quiet erosion of the assumption that technology gets better and more affordable over time.That assumption just died. We're living in its aftermath now, trying to figure out what comes next in a world where the devices we depend on are increasingly treated as luxuries rather than necessities.Welcome to the future. It costs more than you thought.
Article Summary: A global memory chip shortage, driven by insatiable AI data center demand, is skyrocketing prices for everyday electronics. Manufacturers are prioritizing lucrative AI clients, leading to reduced consumer supply. This fundamental market shift means technology is becoming less accessible and more expensive for everyone.

Article Title: Meta India appoints Aman Jain as new head of public policy
Article Text: Meta India has announced the appointment of Aman Jain as the new head of Public Policy to lead the company’s policy strategy and engagements in India. Jain will join the company early next year and will report to Simon Milner, Vice President of Policy, Asia Pacific (APAC). In this role, Aman will also be a member of the India leadership team.Aman will brings over 20 years of public policy and business strategy experience to the social media giant, with a proven track record at Amazon , Google, the Government of India, and international organizations. He has held senior roles at Google India, including Country Head for Government Affairs & Public Policy. Most recently, he served as Director of Public Policy at Amazon, leading policy strategy across marketplace, operations, competition, and technology.On the appointment, Simon Milner, Vice President of Policy, Asia Pacific, said: “India is a strategic market for Meta. As the country’s digital economy accelerates across areas such as AI, emerging tech and the creator economy, Meta aims to help build a more inclusive, trusted, and future-ready internet ecosystem for India.I’m pleased to welcome Aman as Head of Public Policy in India. His extensive experience in public policy and technology, will help Meta be an even more effective partner to regulators and industry stakeholders in developing an enabling policy environment. He will also be a strong addition to Meta’s APAC Policy leadership team.”
Article Summary: Aman Jain will report to Simon Milner, Vice President of Policy, Asia Pacific. Jain brings over 20 years of public policy and business strategy experience to the social media giant. He has held senior roles at Google India, including Country Head for Government Affairs & Public Policy.

Article Title: Elon Musk 'corrects' California Governor Gavin Newsom: You are wrong, my daughters are Azure, Exa and Arcadia, and they do indeed ...
Article Text:
Elon Musk’s relationship with estranged daughter





Elon Musk responded sharply to a social media post by California Governor Gavin Newsom that mocked the tech billionaire’s relationship with his estranged daughter Vivian. In a video post on X (formerly Twitter), Newsom can be seen saying “I want to see trans kids. .. There’s no governor that’s done more pro trans legislation than I have.” The video was sarcastically endorsed by the official Twitter handle of Gavin Newsom Press Office with a rather harsh comment – “Correct. We’re sorry your daughter hates you, Elon.”The Tesla CEO responded to the jab, correcting Gavin Newsom Press Office’s post. Musk clarified that his son Xavier (now Vivian Jenna Wilson) suffers from what he calls a "woke mind virus" while affirming love for him and contrasting with his daughters' affection.“I assume you’re referring to my son, Xavier, who has a tragic mental illness caused by the evil woke mind virus you push on vulnerable children,” Elon Musk wrote adding “I love Xavier very much and hope he recovers.”“My daughters are Azure, Exa (she goes by Y) and Arcadia, and they do indeed love me very much,” Musk further stated.The exchange marks another public clash between Elon Musk and Gavin Newsom, who have frequently disagreed on issues such as tech regulation, COVID-19 policies, and LGBTQ+ rights.Musk has repeatedly criticized what he calls “woke ideology,” while Newsom has defended California’s stance on gender-affirming care and other social policies.Wilson, born in 2004, is the daughter of Elon Musk and author Justine Wilson. Assigned male at birth and originally named Xavier Alexander Musk, she came out as transgender in 2020, adopting the name Vivian Jenna Wilson, taking her mother's maiden name to distance herself from her father.She has often expressed her dislike for Musk, criticizing and calling him a ‘pathetic man-child’. She also distanced herself from Musk's other children, expressing uncertainty about the number of her half-siblings. “I will say I do not actually know how many siblings I have, if you include half-siblings,” she said. “I don’t really give a f**k what they do. This is not my problem, OK?”Musk, on the other hand, has blamed 'woke mind' virus that 'killed' his son.
Article Summary: Elon Musk responded sharply to a social media post by California Governor Gavin Newsom that mocked the tech billionaire’s relationship with his estranged daughter Vivian. Musk clarified that his son Xavier (now Vivian Jenna Wilson) suffers from what he calls a "woke mind virus" while affirming love for him.

Article Title: Google's 'secret weapon' in AI race against OpenAI is what has been giving nightmares to Nvidia
Article Text:
Nvidia Makes History: First Company to Hit $4 Trillion Market Cap

How Google has become a 'worry' for Nvidia

What Nvidia said in its big defense





Nvidia recently got so spooked by a report on Google that the company made a public post on X, formerly Twitter, to defend itself. As for the news: A report in Information claimed that one of Nvidia's biggest customers, Meta, is considering shifting part of its AI infrastructure to Google’s in-house chips, called TPUs or Tensor Processing Units. These TPUs are what analysts consider Google’s secret weapon in the artificial intelligence race against OpenAI. These are chips that have helped Google models leap ahead of OpenAI, prompting tech investors to reassess a new threat to OpenAI as well as Nvidia’s dominance.Google's “tensor processing unit” has been central to the company's efforts to boost the performance of its all-new Gemini 3 AI models, which are reported to have outperformed OpenAI’s GPT-5 in independent benchmarking tests and impressed both analysts and reviewers. These TPUs also power Google Gemini 3 AI models that reportedly made OpenAI CEO Sam Altman send Code Red memos to employees across the company.For almost the past decade, Google’s TPUs were viewed by the industry as a potent but insular tool -- highly efficient custom silicon designed specifically for Google’s internal ecosystem. Now, the tech giant appears ready to break that isolation, launching a strategic offensive to challenge Nvidia’s near-monopoly on the AI hardware market. According to a new report from The Information earlier this year, Google is actively approaching smaller cloud computing providers with a proposition to install its TPUs alongside Nvidia’s GPUs in their data centers.This move signals a significant shift in strategy as Google attempts to position its custom silicon as a viable alternative to the industry standard.However, the landscape is shifting. Google’s recent launch of Gemini 3 -- a model trained entirely on TPUs that rivals OpenAI’s top-tier offerings -- has served as a powerful proof of concept. The success of Gemini 3 challenges the long-held narrative that top-flight AI requires Nvidia hardware, validating the TPU architecture for high-level generative AI work.Google’s outreach to external cloud providers appears to serve a dual purpose. First, it attempts to stimulate broader market demand for its silicon, offering an alternative to Nvidia’s expensive hardware. Second, it addresses a logistical hurdle: Google reportedly has an ample supply of chips but lacks the physical data center speed to deploy them. By partnering with external infrastructure providers, Google could ostensibly offload the hosting while securing the compute capacity needed for its own internal AI demands.This strategy builds on an earlier Information report from June that said that even OpenAI has explored using Google TPUs to offset the high costs of Nvidia’s ecosystem, though likely only for a fraction of its compute load. While Nvidia maintains that its upcoming Blackwell architecture is "a generation ahead," Google’s aggressive push into external data centers suggests the era of the GPU monopoly may be facing its most serious test yet.In a post on X, soon after the Meta and Google news, Nvidia wrote, "We’re delighted by Google’s success—they’ve made great advances in AI, and we continue to supply to Google. Nvidia is a generation ahead of the industry—it’s the only platform that runs every AI model and does it everywhere computing is done."
Article Summary: Google's TPUs are what analysts consider Google’s secret weapon in the artificial intelligence race against OpenAI. One of Nvidia's biggest customers, Meta, is considering shifting part of its AI infrastructure to Google's in-house chips. Google is actively approaching smaller cloud computing providers with a proposition to install its T PUs alongside Nvidia's GPUs in their data centers.

Article Title: Donald Trump signs order blocking states from imposing AI rules, says US needs ‘one central source of approval’
Article Text:
US President Trump Signs AI Power Order: Blocks States, Cites Urgent Threat From China

AI Litigation Task Force to be established soon





Donald Trump has signed a new executive order refraining states from passing artificial intelligence (AI) regulations which his administration believes could limit US leadership in technology. The order, signed on December 11 also directs the federal government to withhold broadband funding from states whose laws to regulate AI conflict with federal priorities. “We want to have one central source of approval,” Trump told reporters.“To win, United States AI companies must be free to innovate without cumbersome regulation,” the order said, adding different state laws make compliance more challenging.“First, State-by-State regulation by definition creates a patchwork of 50 different regulatory regimes that makes compliance more challenging, particularly for start-ups. Second, State laws are increasingly responsible for requiring entities to embed ideological bias within models,” the order stated.“Third, State laws sometimes impermissibly regulate beyond State borders, impinging on interstate commerce,” it added.The order also targets state-level anti-discrimination rules for AI systems. It says such laws could introduce “ideological bias” and produce inaccurate results. Critics, however, warn that removing state authority may reduce safety protections for users.The order also reflects the Trump administration's broader attack against anti-discrimination efforts, taking aim at states such as Colorado that have sought to prevent discriminatory language from being embedded in AI models. Such efforts could result in "ideological bias" and produce false results, it said.As per the executive order, the Attorney General shall establish an AI Litigation Task Force (Task Force) within 30 days of the order’s date. This task force shall be responsible to challenge State AI laws inconsistent with the policy set forth in section 2 of this order, including on grounds that such laws unconstitutionally regulate interstate commerce, are preempted by existingThe Task Force shall consult from time to time with the Special Advisor for AI and Crypto, the Assistant to the President for Science and Technology, the Assistant to the President for Economic Policy, and the Assistant to the President and Counsel to the President regarding the emergence of specific State AI laws that warrant challenge, the order states.
Article Summary: US President Donald Trump has signed a new executive order refraining states from passing artificial intelligence (AI) regulations. The order also directs the federal government to withhold broadband funding from states whose laws to regulate AI conflict with federal priorities. “We want to have one central source of approval,” Trump told reporters.

Article Title: TIME Magazine’s 2025 person of the year is a group including Elon Musk, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, OpenAI's Sam Altman and …
Article Text:
TIME Magazine has named 'The Architects of AI' as its 2025 Person of the Year, recognizing tech leaders like Jensen Huang, Sam Altman, and Elon Musk. These innovators are credited with unleashing AI's full potential, profoundly impacting global information, climate, and our lives.

Two covers of TIME Magazine’s 2025 person of the year

Nvidia Makes History: First Company to Hit $4 Trillion Market Cap





TIME Magazine has announced its ‘2025 Person of the Year’. Only this time, it is not one individual but a group of individuals who has most influenced the news and the world. Called ‘The architects of AI’, the group comprises of Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and xAI CEO Elon Musk among the innovators who "grabbed the wheel of history, developing technology and making decisions that are reshaping the information landscape, the climate, and our livelihoods".“2025 was the year when artificial intelligence’s full potential roared into view, and when it became clear that there will be no turning back,” Time said in its announcement adding “For delivering the age of thinking machines, for wowing and worrying humanity, for transforming the present and transcending the possible, the Architects of AI are TIME’s 2025 Person of the Year.”This year, the magazine released two covers for its Person of the Year issue. One of them – created by digital artist Jason Seiler – pays homage to the famous 1932 photograph of ironworkers casually eating lunch on a steel beam above New York City. It depicts AI leaders like Meta's Mark Zuckerberg, AMD chief Lisa Su, Musk, Huang, Altman as well as Google's AI boss Demis Hassabis, Anthropic's Dario Amodei and Stanford professor Fei-Fei Li."Racing both beside and against each other, they placed multibillion-dollar bets on one of the biggest physical infrastructure projects of all time," the magazine said of the group."They reoriented government policy, altered geopolitical rivalries, and brought robots into homes. AI emerged as arguably the most consequential tool in great-power competition since the advent of nuclear weapons."The second cover has been created by illustrator and graphics animator Peter Crowther. This one also features the same leaders amid a construction scaffolding that surrounds the letters AI.The magazine has bestowed the Person of the Year title annually since 1927. Last year’s Time Person of the Year was US President Donald Trump.
Article Summary: Time Magazine has named 'The Architects of AI' as its 2025 Person of the Year. These innovators are credited with unleashing AI's full potential, profoundly impacting global information, climate, and our lives. The group comprises of Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and xAI CEO Elon Musk.

Article Title: US State department bans a 'Font', reason: It is 'Woke' and ...
Article Text: Secretary of State Marco Rubio has banned Calibri font. Yes, Rubio has passed an order halting the State Department’s official use of Calibri, reversing a 2023 Biden-era directive. Reason is said to be Font's association with diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility. It was reportedly chosen by the department’s then-DEI office, which has since been disbanded under Rubio amid the Trump administration’s anti-DEI directives. Rubio called Biden government's move to Calibri font a “wasteful” sop to diversity. For those unaware, Calibri is a sans-serif font.Rubio’s directive, obtained by The New York Times, comes under the subject line “Return to Tradition: Times New Roman 14-Point Font Required for All Department Paper.” In the “Action Request” memo, Rubio has said that switching back to the use of Times New Roman would “restore decorum and professionalism to the department’s written work.” Calibri is “informal” when compared to serif typefaces like Times New Roman, the order reads, and “clashes” with the department’s official letterhead.“Switching to Calibri achieved nothing except the degradation of the department’s official correspondence,” the memo says.It further notes that Times New Roman had been the department’s official typeface for nearly 20 years until the 2023 change.The choice to adopt a sans-serif font was an effort to improve readability for the visually impaired. With their lack of decorative flourishes and wider letter spacing, fonts like Calibri are often viewed as more accessible for those with conditions ranging from low vision to dyslexia. However, the switch has not been universally embraced.When the Biden administration introduced the change in 2023, it sparked "rumblings" among traditionalists who preferred the classic Times New Roman. Beyond the aesthetic debate, Secretary Blinken also raised the standard font size from 14 to 15-point, a move that irritated diplomats by requiring additional keystrokes to manage document length.
Article Summary: Secretary of State Marco Rubio has banned the State Department's use of Calibri font. The move was made by the Biden administration in 2023. Font's association with diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility is said to be the reason.

Article Title: Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu: We use AI coding tools across the company, with caution to engineers that ...
Article Text:
Junior developers building cross-team tools with AI assistance

Zoho's measured approach contrasts with industry-wide AI mandates





Zoho CEO Sridhar Vembu has revealed that the Indian SaaS giant is now using AI coding tools across the company, with engineers reporting dramatic productivity improvements. In a detailed post on X, Vembu shared how one of the company's most productive engineers—a veteran with two decades of experience—is now completing in one day what previously took three weeks.However, Vembu emphasized a critical condition: all AI-generated code must be reviewed and approved by engineers who take full responsibility for it. "We use AI coding tools across the company - with the caution to engineers that they have to review and approve all the code and take responsibility for it," he wrote, adding that Zoho doesn't "force feed or mandate AI tools" but leaves implementation decisions to experienced engineers.The productivity gains have been substantial. Speaking about a senior engineer handling performance-critical UI work, Vembu said: "He told me that he is now shipping features that would have taken him 3 weeks of work that he got done in a day. AI needed him to provide the structure, it fleshed out the details and that required him to draw on his experience."The technology's impact extends beyond accelerating senior engineers.Vembu disclosed that a less experienced team member built an internal tool with AI that is now being used across other teams—work that wouldn't have been possible without AI assistance. "One of his less experienced team members has built an internal tool with AI that is being used across other teams. He said that team members could not have built the tool without AI," Vembu noted.For UI development specifically, Vembu reported the team is "very bullish on AI," finding the technology particularly effective for interface work that balances functionality with performance demands.Vembu's disclosure comes as major tech companies push aggressive AI adoption targets. Google CEO Sundar Pichai recently said over 25% of new code at Google is AI-generated, while Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella disclosed up to 30% of Microsoft's codebase now comes from AI. Shopify has made AI usage a baseline expectation in performance reviews.Zoho is taking a different path. "We don't force feed or mandate AI tools, and leave the decision on how best to use AI to experienced engineers," Vembu stated. The approach reflects his earlier warnings about technical debt, security vulnerabilities and compliance failures that can accumulate in AI-generated code without proper human oversight.The Zoho founder's comments also follow his recent public clash with Y Combinator President Garry Tan, who predicted companies like Zoho would be among the first casualties of "vibe coding"—where non-technical users build custom apps using AI platforms. Vembu dismissed the claim, pointing to Zoho's customer base growing at over 50% and warning that AI-generated applications accumulate unsustainable technical debt without proper engineering oversight.
Article Summary: Zoho CEO Sridhar Vembu has revealed that the Indian SaaS giant is now using AI coding tools across the company. Engineers reporting dramatic productivity improvements. Zoho doesn't "force feed or mandate AI tools" but leaves implementation decisions to experienced engineers.

Article Title: The simple career lesson that Apple founder Steve Jobs shared with students at Stanford commencement speech: Doing the …
Article Text:
Turning a career setback into major creative work period

I never did it for money: Steve Jobs





Nearly two decades after it was delivered, Apple founder Steve Jobs ’ Stanford commencement speech continues to resonate with and inspire professionals. The Commencement Address delivered by Jobs on June 12, 2005 has a ‘simple’ career lesson for young people – the importance of doing the work you love – a principle he said kept him going over the years. “Your work is going to fill a large part of your life, and the only way to be truly satisfied is to do what you believe is great work. And the only way to do great work is to love what you do,” Jobs told students then.“If you haven’t found it yet, keep looking—and don’t settle. As with all matters of the heart, you’ll know when you find it,” he continued.Despite being one of the co-founders of Apple , Steve Jobs was pushed out of the company in 1985 by the then CEO John Sculley. However, Jobs said it was then he entered one of the “most creative periods” by launching NeXT and revamping Pixar Studios.Even so, Jobs said he felt drawn back to Apple, calling it the “best thing that ever happened to [him].” He returned as CEO in 1997 and stayed in the role until two months before his death in October 2011.“Sometimes life hits you in the head with a brick. Don’t lose faith,” Jobs said. “I’m convinced that the only thing that kept me going was that I loved what I did.You’ve got to find what you love.”In a 1996 interview with PBS, Jobs revealed that despite becoming a millionaire at at the age of 23, it wasn’t ‘important’ to him because he “never did it for the money.”“I was worth about over $1 million when I was 23, and over $10 million when I was 24, and over $100 million when I was 25,” Jobs told PBS. “And it wasn’t that important, because I never did it for the money.”
Article Summary: Apple founder Steve Jobs delivered the Stanford Commencement Address on June 12, 2005. He said the only way to be truly satisfied is to do what you believe is great work. Jobs was pushed out of Apple in 1985 by the then CEO John Sculley.

Article Title: OpenAI launches GPT 5.2 with advanced capabilities, to compete with Google’s Gemini 3
Article Text:
'Trump Needs Indian Skilled Workers': Expert On Big Tech's AI Bet On India

Coding with GPT 5.2





ChatGPT-maker OpenAI has launched GPT-5.2 artificial intelligence model, days after CEO Sam Altman issued an internal "code red" pausing internal projects and redirecting teams to accelerate development. This comes as a response to Google 's Gemini 3 that was launched last month. Announcing the new model, OpenAI said “We designed GPT‑5.2 to unlock even more economic value for people; it’s better at creating spreadsheets, building presentations, writing code, perceiving images, understanding long contexts, using tools, and handling complex, multi-step projects.”As revealed by the company, the new models is aimed to bring more economic value for users.“GPT‑5.2 Thinking sets a new state-of-the-art score, and is our first model that performs at or above a human expert level. Specifically, GPT‑5.2 Thinking beats or ties top industry professionals on 70.9% of comparisons on GDPval knowledge work tasks, according to expert human judges. These tasks include making presentations, spreadsheets, and other artifacts,” the company said.OpenAI says that GPT‑5.2 Thinking sets a new state of the art of 55.6% on SWE-Bench Pro, a rigorous evaluation of real-world software engineering.Unlike SWE-bench Verified, which only tests Python, SWE-Bench Pro tests four languages and aims to be more contamination-resistant, challenging, diverse, and industrially relevant.On SWE-bench Verified (not plotted), GPT‑5.2 Thinking scored 80%, as claimed by the AI maker. “For everyday professional use, this translates into a model that can more reliably debug production code, implement feature requests, refactor large codebases, and ship fixes end-to-end with less manual intervention,” it said.OpenAI further claims GPT‑5.2 Thinking hallucinates less than GPT‑5.1 Thinking. On a set of de-identified queries from ChatGPT, responses with errors were 30%rel less common. For professionals, this means fewer mistakes when using the model for research, writing, analysis, and decision support—making the model more dependable for everyday knowledge work.
Article Summary: ChatGPT-maker OpenAI has launched GPT-5.2 artificial intelligence model. CEO Sam Altman issued an internal "code red" pausing internal projects and redirecting teams to accelerate development. This comes as a response to Google's Gemini 3 that was launched last month.

Article Title: PhonePe Wealth launches daily SIPs starting at Rs 10
Article Text: PhonePe Wealth has announced the launch of its Daily SIP (Systematic Investment Plan) feature in mutual funds, enabling users to invest as little as ₹10 per day directly through the PhonePe app. The initiative aims to make investing more accessible, habitual, and affordable for millions of Indians, turning everyday savings into long-term wealth creation.The new Daily SIP feature allows investors to commit micro amounts daily, offering flexibility and convenience for individuals with regular cash flows. Users can set up SIPs seamlessly via UPI Autopay, choose from curated funds across equity, gold, and multi-asset categories, and adjust contributions based on their comfort and goals. Importantly, SIPs can be stopped anytime, with invested money continuing to compound.Nilesh D Naik, head of investment products at Share.Market (PhonePe Wealth), said: “With Daily SIPs, we are making investing more habitual for millions of Indians. Even a daily investment of ₹10 encourages disciplined, long-term investing and helps overcome short-term market volatility. Our goal is to simplify investing and help every Indian participate in the country’s growth story.”The Daily SIP feature is expected to empower both first-time investors and seasoned participants, fostering a culture of disciplined, long-term wealth creation.
Article Summary: PhonePe Wealth has announced the launch of its Daily SIP (Systematic Investment Plan) feature in mutual funds. Users can set up SIPs seamlessly via UPI Autopay, choose from curated funds across equity, gold, and multi-asset categories.

Article Title: Waymo recalls over 3,000 vehicles in the US: Here’s why
Article Text:
Waymo responds





Google-parent Alphabet owned electric vehicle maker Waymo has recalled 3,067 of its vehicles in the United States, reports news agency Reuters., The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) said that the recall was done over a software issue which was fixed through an update.As per the report, the EV company had recalled certain vehicles with the 5th generation automated driving systems (ADS) operating with software that caused vehicles to drive past stopped school buses, increasing the risk of a crash, the regulator said.Waymo, as per NHTSA, has updated the software and all impacted vehicles were repaired by November 17 this year.Last week, Waymo announced a recall for its self-driving vehicles after Texas officials said the vehicles illegally passed school buses at least 19 times since the start of the school year. The EV maker then said that a software issue caused its self-driving cars to first slow down or stop for a school bus and then move forward. Waymo further stated that it will keep monitoring the system and roll out more updates if needed.NHTSA opened an investigation into Waymo cars in October this year. It has now asked the company to provide details about the incidents in Texas by January 20, the report said.
Article Summary: Waymo has recalled 3,067 of its vehicles in the United States. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) said that the recall was done over a software issue. Texas officials said the vehicles illegally passed school buses at least 19 times since the start of the school year.

Article Title: Google’s AI team DeepMind announces first ‘automated research lab’
Article Text:
Google DeepMind ‘ automated research lab ’ to offer priority access for British scientists







Google DeepMind has unveiled plans to establish its first “automated research lab” in the United Kingdom, expanding its AI-driven scientific research capabilities. The facility is set to open next year and it will leverage advanced AI and robotics systems to conduct autonomous experiments, with an initial focus on developing novel superconductor materials for medical imaging technology and new semiconductor materials.The announcement of the lab comes as part of a broader partnership between DeepMind – Google’s artificial intelligence division – and the UK government.Under the partnership agreement, British scientists will receive “priority access” to some of the world's most sophisticated AI tools, according to the UK government's announcement. This access is expected to accelerate research and innovation across multiple scientific disciplines, positioning British researchers at the forefront of AI-assisted discovery. Moreover, the potential applications span nuclear fusion research and the deployment of DeepMind's Gemini AI models across government departments and educational institutions throughout the region.“DeepMind serves as the perfect example of what UK-US tech collaboration can deliver—a firm with roots on both sides of the Atlantic backing British innovators to shape the curve of technological progress,” said UK Technology Secretary Liz Kendall in a statement.“This agreement could help to unlock cleaner energy, smarter public services, and new opportunities which will benefit communities up and down the country,” Kendall added.Meanwhile, Demis Hassabis, DeepMind's founder, expressed enthusiasm about the partnership's potential impact.“AI has incredible potential to drive a new era of scientific discovery and improve everyday life. We're excited to deepen our collaboration with the UK government and build on the country's rich heritage of innovation to advance science, strengthen security, and deliver tangible improvements for citizens," Hassabis said.
Article Summary: Google DeepMind to establish its first “automated research lab” in the United Kingdom. The facility is set to open next year and it will leverage advanced AI and robotics systems to conduct autonomous experiments. Initial focus will be on developing novel superconductor materials for medical imaging technology and new semiconductor materials.
